abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings are as follows: Project
            outcome is moderately satisfactory; sustainability is
            likely; institutional development impact is substantial;
            overall Bank performance is unsatisfactory; and overall
            Borrower performance is satisfactory. The experience of the
            Rajasthan Agriculture Development Project offers four
            lessons for future Bank supported, state-wide multi-sectoral
            interventions in the agriculture sector in India and
            elsewhere. 1) When several policy reforms and investments
            are required in a sector, a multi-phase operation over a
            longer period may be more appropriate. Early attention could
            then be focused on critical policy reforms and the most
            crucial investments to create the right platform for
            subsequent investments. This would avoid the simultaneous
            preoccupation with meeting multiple targets at the expense
            of a sound policy framework. 2) Monitoring and evaluation of
            outcomes should be integral to project design. Realistic
            targets and indicators need to be linked to objectives. 3)
            Complex Bank interventions require strong and constant Bank
            management oversight to ensure the alignment of
            implementation and design and strict adherence to Bank
            procedures and policies. 4) Adequate understanding of the
            financial situation of the government at the appraisal stage
            can help ensure the financial health of a project during
            implementation and the sustainability of activities
            supported after closure.

6538404.trustfund:
TF020400-NETHERLANDS' CONSULTANTS
            TRUST FUND,TF025240-PHRD-AGRICULTURAL DEVELOPMENT II

abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is rated satisfactory.
            Sustainability is likely and depends on the effectiveness of
            the arrangements made for their future operation and
            management. Both World Bank and Borrower performances are
            rated as satisfactory overall. The list of lessons learned
            includes the following: This complex operation involving 12
            government departments made Borrower coordination and
            monitoring and World Bank supervision difficult. It would
            have been better had investments concentrated on fewer
            critical areas that responded most directly to objectives,
            were technically robust, and had a higher chance of success.
            Performance was generally better in those departments that
            commissioned activity evaluation studies early enough and
            then took decisive remedial actions. Continuity of key staff
            contributes to successful implementation. Under typically
            harsh field conditions, especially when migratory practices
            are followed, animal breeding programs should avoid use of
            exotic stock and focus upgrading on selection within the
            locally adapted breeds (except for intensive dairying).
            Future programs should focus on fewer high quality
            demonstrations of technologies with good replication
            prospects. While the project reform agenda successfully
            focused on introducing full cost recovery on selected farm
            inputs, relatively little was included to promote income
            generation and financial sustainability in the implementing departments.

repnme.cdata!:
India - Agricultural Development Project
            for Rajasthan

abstracts.cdata!:
The project will address the problems of
            agricultural development in Rajasthan through a broad
            approach linking policy reforms and public investments. The
            project's objectives are to: accelerate the growth of
            agriculture through improved technical, financial and
            economic use of resources; enhance sustainability of the
            productive resource base; and improve equity within the
            sector. Policy reforms will include full cost recovery for
            publicly provided goods and services, reduced inputs
            subsidies, improved efficiency and sustainability of water
            use, institutional reforms of rural cooperatives,
            alleviating constraints to private investment in
            agroindustry, and strengthening of the Government's
            environmental oversight for agriculture. Investment
            components will include crop husbandry, horticulture, animal
            husbandry, water resources, agricultural research and
            training, rural roads, project coordination, and
            environmental strengthening.

docna.cdata!: India - Agricultural Development Project for Rajasthan

India - Agricultural Development
            Project for Rajasthan
